posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
Here is a clean-up version of the text:

---

The text is about creating a through-bore encoder upgrade for MAXSpline. Here are the key points:

- A configuration option exists to switch between MAXSpline and SplineXL bore if preferred
- The design builds on a previous implementation by Redux’s through-bore upgrade
- Uses 3D printed parts to create a 3D space for the MAXSpline gear
- Includes 6807±15mm helical N6747AE bearings and 10mm ID ±1553mm bore to support the encoder gear
- The case is made from 3D printed aluminum and features 3D printed pins for supporting the MAXSpline wheel
- Uses 6807±15mm bearings for the MAXSpline gear
- The baseplate is 647x500 pixels with a 647x500 source image
- The mechanism uses 647x500 pixels for the MAXSpline wrapper
- There is a design option with 10mm ID bearings instead of equivalent ones
- Two versions are available:
  - V1 with REV Through bore
  - V1 with REV Through bore and encoder
- The REV Through bore version doubles the backlash due to having two sets of gears
- Instructions include building the design using standard engineering software
- The design file includes standard components like meta tags, filenames, and information
- The text provides detailed troubleshooting and design considerations

--- 

This version removes all HTML tags, converts lightbox-wrapper and download-href attributes to placeholders, while preserving the core technical information.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Excellent, been missing for a while, thanks Eliot. There will likely be some experimentation involved in getting the slipfit just right on the spline gear interface. Since this component is 3D printed, optimizing the design to utilize the available space on the spline could be beneficial. Given the extensive use of splines on this gear, exploring ways to enhance interface compatibility through features like nubbins or tabs might be worthwhile. A key consideration is addressing backlash and accommodating printer variability, both of which are critical for reliable performance. Additionally, testing whether a single bearing on the magnet gear suffices is an ongoing aspect of this project.

posts.name: Andrew Schreiber
posts.cooked: (That is all CD, stop asking if this is a complete sentence)

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: Hm, that's really interesting—I might end up playing with compliant mechanisms for the fit. I'm also a bit worried about how well the gears will print to reduce backlash. In my gear featurescript, there are some configurable options in the main model, but I'm unsure how effective that will be. Currently, the spline clearance is configurable. I have an image here showing the gears. Maybe I'll have an excuse for a resin printer to print it. Hopefully, someone can test the fit soon.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: I think you are correct to go with gears here, for ease and accessibility. Let us suppose for a moment it is designed for ±180°, can you bias the encoder gear to one side with a lightweight torsion (clock mainspring style) or extension spring/rubber band? That way you won't need to chase super-fine DP gears. This does make installing such that the preload is correct a bit more of a pain.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: Experimentation will determine if the single bearing on the magnet gear is sufficient. It doesn’t fit right with me in my brain but this is how both the REV through bore and how the Redux through bore work. So I assume it will translate to this design. If not I guess I need to try and design some bushing in there. The gears are also herringbone so I hope that helps the magnet gear stay in. This does make assembly quite a bit harder as well as increasing the part count. Doing research into springs might be interesting. There are other relatively straightforward zero backlash solutions outside of gears as well. I did look into belts I really wouldn’t trust a cantileversed pulley with this setup. I’m not sure what other ways I could look into.

posts.name: Eeshwar Krishnan
posts.cooked: This is extremely cool! Super excited to download the files and try a test print of it.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: Awesome work! I'll definitely print one soon to check it out. One question, why the 6807 bearing over 6707? Easier to source?

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: This is extremely cool! I look forward to seeing what’s able to be improved after initial testing.
This is one of those items I didn’t know I needed until I saw it, but it would have made our arm encoder so much simpler for our bot last year.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: Today was my first time learning about different metric bearing IDs/numbers, so I relied on information from vendor’s webpages and people on discord. I think I'll go with the 6807 bearing now because it's easier to source and available from frc vendors.

posts.name: Ryan Dognaux
posts.cooked: This is super cool, nice work @Eliot.

posts.name: Greg Billetdeaux
posts.cooked:
I printed and did a test assembly without an encoder today. The encoder gear tends to float up and down due to gravity, causing it to rub against the thin-walled top plate, which already has a very thin wall near the encoder. Additionally, the herringbone mechanism isn't sufficient to keep it in place. While improving tolerancing for a better press-fit could help, simply adding a threaded end to the gear—with a small bolt and washer—could securely retain it against the bearing, reducing reliance on printer settings. This approach seems effective and straightforward.  

This innovation is quite impressive—we'll keep it in mind for future endeavors involving splines.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
I just printed V10 (I’ve been doing a lot of iterations). I received three images showing different builds, including PXL_20240815_210656102.MP, PXL_20240815_210701160, and PXL_20240815_210741546, all optimized for viewing. I have the large bearings now; the small ones will arrive on Monday along with two Canadmags, which were sent for free. I plan to print one with my friend’s bamboo instead of my Enders 3 V2 for potentially better tolerances.  

I realized I needed to add more tolerance for hole sizes and made those adjustments. Someone mentioned adding a threaded end to a gear to keep it aligned with the bearing. That might help reduce wear. However, the magnets with the Canandmags are 0.5” long, which takes up significant space. I increased the wall thickness between the encoder and gear, so it shouldn’t wear out quickly.  

The gears aren’t meshing properly at the C-C due to printer tolerance issues, leading me to consider making a C-C adder in the next version.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Could you make a small bushing surface to touch off on the magnet with a bit of clearance? I know it is far from ideal but the loads are very low radially so you may be just fine.

Clocking marks are always appreciated to help get things aligned properly or at least good enough if taken apart in the pits for the spline and the gears.

Good work so far!

posts.name: Eeshwar Krishnan
posts.cooked:
The magnet included with the Canandmag is 0.5" long, causing it to take up considerable space. I increased the wall thickness between the encoder and the gear to reduce wear. Using stronger magnets, such as those with N30 grade and over 6mm x 2mm size, helps prevent excessive wear. I prefer magnets from radial-magnets.inc, but a thicker option might be better suited for this application. Interestingly, the included magnet still works well.  

The BOM increase is minimal, though any diametrically magnetized magnet with sufficient strength can be used. I recommend magnets from radial-magnets.inc; they're popular for various projects, though a thicker magnet might be more durable here. The included magnet is surprisingly effective.  

The encoder fit looks decent despite poor print quality; it was printed at 200% speed on a Model 3S.  

This concludes the necessary information without additional fluff.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: I just got all of the parts and had my friend use his P1 to 3d print them. Backlash seems under 0.5 degrees, but measuring it precisely is tricky since the hardware only offers 0.36 degree resolution without CAN. The main problem is the encoder's loose mount; its tightness likely varies by printer. Maybe adjusting preset settings based on the printer could help. Overall, I’m quite pleased with this!

Maybe just set preset or configurable tolerances? It may take time to collect data from several or even individual printers. The tolerance settings can vary depending on the environment and the type of filament used.

The resolution on REV’s hardware client is 0.36 degrees, so it’s hard to measure…
